As I tackle the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the less pleasant aspects first. I strongly dislike pre-quals as they often hinder the story's progression, moving backwards rather than forwards. While it does provide more story depth, the combat feels somewhat sloppy and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City achieved. As of my writing this recommendation (October 26, 2013), a game-breaking bug persists, preventing a side mission from ever being completed (the main story remains unaffected). Some gadgets are inconveniently assigned to a hotkey, requiring a tedious keyboard journey to access them. Although this may seem minor, it could potentially disrupt combat combos during gameplay.

They effectively fixed Shadow Warrior (2013), i.e., the boss fights are impressive, weapons feel very pleasant (perhaps not as excellent as D44m's ones, but still solid), enemies aren't overly spongy (if you're not too inept with handling elemental and upgrade items). The upgrade system is well-balanced and once you master it, it's not overly tedious. The elemental abilities and limited ammunition encourage you to use different weapons. Many unique (notably, the crucial aspect here while comparing Sw2 to Borderlands' formula of 'rng' weapons) weapons remain viable throughout most of the game. The music is excellent, particularly the main theme and, of course, Stan Bush's contributions.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death lead to some frustration. Yes, this is a nostalgic trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irksome Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, and seamlessly woven into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon's excellent War for/Energon games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g., Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a bit, but it didn't impress me. The login process took more time than the actual gameplay. There's a minor bug that pops up a message about an update to the terms of service, but clicking 'accept' doesn't work and requires a client restart. I'm not thrilled about linking my Steam and GFace accounts, as it's unnecessary for DLC and not reversible. Now, I'm concerned that a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is unoriginal, being easily recognizable as a Call of Duty clone. They somehow managed to make the gunplay even worse, which is puzzling.

4K+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and Neptune Gear included. What's not to love? https //www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo An excellent port, making it a great entry point for those new to the series. Keep in mind that there is some (skip-able) dialogue. As usual, I recommend using a gamepad, but I had no issues with a keyboard/mouse setup, both fully rebindable. The price is reasonable, and I wouldn't have been unhappy with a purchase. More than half the DLC is included for free, providing plenty to play with. I highly recommend this game to JRPG, anime, and visual novel fans, assuming you're comfortable with occasional long breaks between action sequences. Cheers. No commentary playlist  https //www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1

I experienced no performance issues even at release, and after all these patches, the game plays really well. In my opinion, this is a truly great and fun game in truth, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play Batman + 1 more), and the ability to use the controller for most segments of the game, while using the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving your Batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the APC commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you figure out how to use the brakes to skid around corners (and when you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable).

Fantastic FPS shooter - that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays great - excellent FPS mechanics, engaging story, well-developed characters, and a fantastic soundtrack. Not for the faint of heart, though - some cutscenes were quite intense and graphic. However, when a game is this great, it's easier to overlook the flaws, and here they are as I saw them  a lack of simultaneous support for multiple graphics cards. I had to put the game away until I upgraded my graphics card, as it ran poorly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Be sure to have a decent single-GPU card.

English is not my native language, so I'll forgive any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I'll break down this review into a few categories  graphics, controls, sound, and replayability. Graphics  the game features a comic-like style, with very slick graphics and nice color schemes. The graphics can be set on 'high' without straining your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor with an Nvidia GeForce 710M card and 8GB of memory, and it runs smoothly (Windows 8.1). Controls  the game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, or with an Xbox controller.

You can see the hours I've invested in this game, which indicates my enthusiasm for it. This is everything I wished a search game from Cod would be. However, I wouldn't recommend this game solely because it's like Cod, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. I've heard numerous times from new players who complain about getting killed quickly. Oh, the horror! It's not like that doesn't happen in real life, or anything. I've been playing this game for a while now, and I've thrown a significant amount of money at it. One of the best multiplayer games around. It's a great game to play when you're not feeling CS GO.

I'm 2 hours in and I'm dying from laughter from this game. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, the story/world has me intrigued, and the puzzles are fun. But the best thing about this game is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll likely laugh at the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you've never played an RPG before, you'll still enjoy the game for its humor. If you played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you absolutely must play this game, without giving away too much... I had to stop playing after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm really sorry, I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution has done nothing for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still just simply didn't find the gameplay itself enjoyable. It also lacks a pause button, or if it does have one, I never found it. Considering that many sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is a lot more cutscene than it is game, and I end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.

This game was an absolute delight from start to finish. I was hooked from the story to the graphics. The narrative wasn't just a story, but I felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the story that my character was telling. Gameplay was excellent and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but I persisted for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this, you created a truly beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization  Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to a specific goal or 'victory'. In previous games, you were set on the Earth's timeline, progressing through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age. In this game, you're set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that it took a new approach to the game and introduced new mechanics such as the Affinity System and Orbital Layer. However, I didn't enjoy that the game could be overwhelming at times. I think that what could be improved is incorporating some new artwork in the game, such as the environment you experience when communicating with another leader.

Great game! This zombie survival game offers tons of replayability and is extremely fun! It's one of the better, more realistic zombie games I've ever played. After playing over 60 hours, I can honestly say this is one of the more realistic zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror, where you must save up your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when you're infected, etc. I find the zombies to feel very natural to be well-animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.  I would recommend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, as the community is super friendly and you can usually make friends/talk with the people in the chat or over voice comms.

February 7, 2014 - Unfortunately, I cannot thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game due to the short time I've played it. I know I would be addicted if it didn't have the following two game-breaking issues. The lack of Australian servers puts you at a severe disadvantage, creating unbearable lag. Moreover, I played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering and lagging as well (it's astonishing that this happened). Additionally, the poor ping rate only adds to the frustration. Everything about the game is chaotic, from the menus to the backgrounds, training, and in-game assets. I've never experienced this issue with this card and initially thought it might not be compatible with my graphics card. Setting my GPU back to stock settings and, sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

Last night, I finished this game. The story is not particularly deep or captivating, but the storytelling is what makes it stand out. The atmosphere is rich and immersive, and the many collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, so it was a bit disappointing that there were so few boss battles. However, there are enough future games to rectify that. The combat is the right amount of challenge, leaning towards the easier side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you acquire and upgrade during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Having access to previously unreachable places makes for a sense of progression.

'To the moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for 'To the Moon!' Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky, and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor is great as well, and it definitely does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the references are endless.

Bastion is a brilliant game, with a truly great storyline. Following a calamity, you begin rebuilding on the bastion. The game offers a wide range of choices, including selecting what to build for an advantage, choosing weapons and power-ups for those weapons, as well as drinks to grant bonus effects. The game's art style and music are fantastic, making the apocalypse seem vibrant and engaging. Furthermore, the game features narration that adapts to the player's actions, so if you pick up a weapon and switch to another in the armory, the narration will acknowledge your change.

I had initially acquired this game during its early development, when the primary currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree' in place. At that time, the game was enjoyable. All the weapons were equally overpowered, so there were no issues with balance; anyone could kill anyone at any moment. Additionally, the game used to provide unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You might expect that for a game with 'billions of guns', they would at least offer more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring payment for additional options. At one point, I had about three pages' worth of weapons, and was conceptualizing new ideas for more, as I found that to be where I derived my enjoyment.

This game was a delightful surprise. One often sees glowing reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews reflect the fun of this charming little game. It's an intriguing blend of a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and it does it with flair. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't normally appreciate in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface are delightfully charming. As such, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

I just started playing, and I'm absolutely enthralled by this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had this level of engagement with me. The music perfectly sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are seamless. I look forward to every combat, and they've executed combat extremely well. I had some initial reservations about the naval combat system, but it's actually a lot of fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at once! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat appears overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counter-attack. Thanks, developers, for an exceptional experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it's certainly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. The game serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear, narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he's introduced into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.

Where do I start on this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is absolutely charming. It has so much detail put into it, and it's a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It's serious when it needs to be, but isn't a stranger to funny moments. The character design is on point, with various characters having distinct personalities and secrets. It stands out from other RPGs because you don't have to kill anyone, which is an unused concept in RPGs. With lots of inspiration from Earthbound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, you can tell it's going to be good. It easily has the best soundtrack I've heard in a while.

I'm recommending this solely because it's free and may provide a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game didn't leave a lasting impression on me. Half the story relies on shock value. I wasn't shocked or emotionally moved in any way by this. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simplistic to elicit a reaction from me. As for the other half of the game, it attempts to paint a vivid picture of a person's mental decline. It explores themes of obsession, hallucinations, depression, and a few other issues. In theory, it's an intriguing concept. However, the game took me 10 minutes to complete, which is reasonable considering the amount of information presented.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that presents a concept and then gets out. It's an amazing way to challenge your mind while still being enjoyable. Although this game isn't as story-driven, it did give birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and enjoy returning to it when I'm feeling bored and love to revisit what gave rise to a legend and what is a legend. Gameplay  Portal's gameplay is relatively straightforward, to explain at least. You utilize portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a portion of the puzzle. Two buttons are present in the game, one that you press and one that requires a cube to place.

If you can overlook the minor bugs (which I personally experienced only two  one minor and the other quite annoying), the edit  both bugs are resolved, and my FPS increased from 60-90 to 80-120. If you're looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews are about specs, I'll include mine  i5 6600k (~200€) Radeon RX 480 (~200€) Z170 Pro - Gaming (~150€) 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€) ~650€ is definitely within the medium price range, although this rig is quite new. Almost constant 60+ FPS on high settings with vsync enabled, I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they're rocking an overkill setup and getting 20 FPS.

Remember the age of mythology? Yes, it's been a while since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity  Dragon Commander comes close to these borders of my personal most favorite RTS game. Combine this with a huge risk-like grand strategy mode, and it hits the spot. I'm not (read  try not to be) overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning at the very same time. Honestly, I do like the complex RTS games nowadays. Think of Civilization V and so on. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources all into one complicated game mode.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The retro aesthetic of the graphics and the music combine to produce truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script masterfully runs the gamut from comedy to drama to heartbreak and even hope, often simultaneously, and achieves this by subverting RPG tropes with ease. Without delving into the world, characters, story, or gameplay mechanics, I could wax poetic about its many virtues. Instead, I'll simply say this  if you're a fan of RPGs, play this game. If you're a gamer, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your mortality, play this game.

I have had this game for a few months, but in just that short period, two DLCs have emerged, along with patches that have transformed an already excellent game into an exceptional one. The developers are very active in the community, and it's evident in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. Although the game's mechanics have a fairly steep learning curve, this breadth of strategy offers a myriad of ways to achieve goals and capitalize on specific situations. In my opinion, the game is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself fully immersed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough is going.

Warframe is a fun game for the initial hours of play. As you progress beyond those few enjoyable hours, you'll notice that the game's offerings begin to dwindle, with repetition dominating its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The redeeming quality is that the developers are actively working to deliver regular updates, which often bring significant changes to the game's systems, new Warframes, and other enhancements. It's an excellent choice for casual play. While I'm skeptical about its long-term appeal, I recommend giving it a try. If you're seeking a quick fix, Warframe is worth a try. Since it's free, there's no harm in giving it a shot.

This game is quite underwhelming. I purchased this game thinking it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it's a far cry from it. In this game, you progress by absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb bigger entities. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels lack inventiveness, and the content is a surreal, unsettling horror experience. I don't mean an entertaining horror experience, but one that leaves you questioning the meaning of life. Every 'living' creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators of this game had an interest in taxidermy.

Alright, let me explain a few things. As someone deeply interested in politics, I was very interested in this game when I first heard about it. I thought, 'Oh wow, a simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!' However, it wasn't as exciting as I had hoped. The game starts you off and asks you to pick a side  Republican or Democrat, with no independent or third-party option. A bit disappointed, but still optimistic, I decided to see what I could do. I'll give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to play around with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.

The Fallout 3 story is better. Settlements often get in the way of the story, making it difficult to play the story. Some keys are hardcoded and cannot be rebound. Bugs abound. My Pip-Boy disappeared permanently at one point and I had to research console commands to get it back. You don't have to work for power armor, as it's basically given to you from the beginning of the game and power cores are readily available in trader shops. The value of power armor has diminished greatly from previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, and everything about this game is average, except it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. Compared to Fallout 3, it's very stable. While it's not better than Fallout 3, it's also not worse. The title was overhyped for how mediocre it actually is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review)  8.6 hours to reach the end, collecting 10 out of 25 collectibles, with zero achievements out of 15. What I liked  The visuals up until the last level (Ice Caves) were impressive. The story is not that great, but the ending, after the closing credits, somewhat redeemed the time I spent playing this game. What I disliked  The visuals in the last level were underwhelming, and the gameplay in the last level became increasingly frustrating, requiring me to repeat tasks numerous times before getting it right. Additionally, the achievements are disappointingly challenging, with only 13 (out of 15) achieved by less than 2.1% of players.

Pros  +graphic Cons  -bugs (especially in the environment, you may get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight of the enemy) -game is hand-holding/babysitting you -dumb AI -enemies always seem to know where you are when you're spotted -godlike accuracy by the enemy, which is frustrating, like the first Ghost Warrior. -terrible checkpoints and saves. -boring story that I couldn't care less about; I won't recommend it unless it's 90% off, even then I find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing for the sake of finishing it to move onto the next game in my library. Considering the time I wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally boring and I feel liberated when I finished it), I probably won't play it until the end.

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? This puzzle-platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large branching map. This game is quite amusing and running through it to complete the game was quite a bit of fun. However, it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements though. To get all the cubes, you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher. These can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking into a guide. The game's guide, 'A Complete Guide to Fez!!!'

It's not difficult for me to see why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. I have a vivid imagination and I'm more interested in playing immersive games with complex controllers. The game's initial scale is awe-inspiring, but it hindered my enjoyment due to the steep learning curve and the significant time commitment required to do anything engaging at the beginning. If I had more patience and more time for gaming, this might be more compelling. However, I don't have either, and there are many other VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required to remain on target. There's no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine all the time, you'll have a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you've caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start by saying I didn't purchase Eu when it first came out, and I got it on sale, which included EU, so I never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game, however, it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM 2, I love it; the game plays pretty well for me on medium, and I'm running a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. At first, the game set it to high and it was running a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable; but when I dropped it down to medium, it smoothed out. Not sure if I'm just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what, but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they're coming from some really entitled people.

RPG levelling offers a wide variety of ship types, physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles, and easy-to-learn resource management. It also has a dark humored grind, but not excessively so. The AI teammates are sub-par, and there's a limited variety of equipment types and leveling skills, with no branching. However, despite these minuses, the game still has some variety and strategy to offer. It starts off fast and maintains a good pace. While there's a limited selection of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to enhance the game is through mods. The fight for universe is easily the main attraction, but the big fight for beef is also very satisfying.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted. Anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEF's more exclusive event in Davos.

Deadline looms for Fiat-GM deal  Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on February 1 to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, after Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The US firm is thought to be offering around $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued that the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticized the Iraq War, stating that the billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East could have been better spent reducing poverty. In a Christmas message, he denounced the war as a "terrible" waste of money. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales reiterated his stance on BBC Radio 4 and will do so again in his Christmas Midnight Mass. The cardinal also echoed the Archbishop of Canterbury's sentiments, who has also spoken out against the war. In his Thought for the Day slot on BBC Radio 4, the cardinal lamented that 'billions' have been spent on war, rather than being used to alleviate poverty, malnutrition, and disease. He called 2005 a year for campaigning to'make history' in the fight against poverty.

British stars' hopes of winning major Oscars were dashed as UK stars failed to take home acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's Vera Drake failed to win the director or screenplay awards, and there was no prize for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost to Best Actress Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okenedo failed to win the Best Supporting Actor awards. The UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film Award for her gritty drama Wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, described it as "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, outshining films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the film made over $60 million worldwide - a record for an independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 1970s that were typically held by men.

According to a UK think-tank report, a quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and maintain personal websites, with more than five million households in the UK having broadband connections and that number growing rapidly. The report highlights how having an always-on, fast internet connection is transforming the way people use the internet. More than half of those with broadband log on to the web before breakfast, while one in five admit to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. Significantly, the report suggests that broadband is empowering people to take a more active role online.

Yukos heading back to US courts, Russian oil and gas company Yukos is due in a US court on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by Russian authorities to pay a $27 billion ($14 billion) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yurganskneftegas. The unit was, however, sold for $9.4 billion to state oil firm Rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.

Voters are flocking to the blog awards site to cast their votes in the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best weblogs - online spaces where people share their thoughts of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that it was temporarily closed due to the overwhelming number of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs have had a remarkable year, with the term "blog" being named Word of the Year in 2004. According to Technorati, a blog search engine, it tracks around six million blogs and notes that more than 12,000 are added daily. Research from the Pew Internet and American Life project suggests that a new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, but less than 40% of the total blogs are updated at least once every two months.

China's dam firm 'defies Beijing' the China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the Chinese state press has said. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, said the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction projects called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The Beijing News said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales'must learn health lessons' says the new health minister, who notes that there are valuable lessons to be learned from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the role after Jane Hutt's departure, acknowledged "big challenges" but emphasized that the "essentials" are already in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats called for policy changes from Dr. Gibbons. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, stating that waiting times and lists comprise only 10% of the health agenda. Dr. Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, and AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff desire a period of consolidation following "tremendous change and reform". One of the biggest issues Ms. Hutt faced during her five-and-a-half years as the Assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Manchester United's resolve, Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season, and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come, and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also hailed senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield, which we needed, and which no other player has got.

Singer George Michael's documentary film will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival, offering a candid look at his life and career. The 93-minute film will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, running from February 10-20. Michael will attend the festival on February 16 to introduce the screening. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also attend the festival. The documentary features Michael discussing his early days in Wham! as well as his later career, including his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter the US singles chart digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams is currently number two on Billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales, but confines its airplay information to US radio stations which play chart music.

Scott Richter, the self-proclaimed spam king, is seeking bankruptcy protection for his company, Optinrealbig.com, which has been forced into Chapter 11 due to lawsuits. The company, listed as the third-largest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, was sued in December 2003 for sending millions of spam messages that violated anti-spam laws. Microsoft and the New York Attorney General's office, led by Eliot Spitzer, alleged that Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini, Tottenham's sporting director, Frank Arnesen, has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini had felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. He has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." Arnesen said he was unable to shed any light on the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added  "Santini has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past Scotland at Murrayfield, maintaining their six-nation Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy come to Edinburgh, but they struggled to turn pressure into points.

Economy will be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has said, as he spoke after the Cabinet meeting at No 10 Downing Street before the election announcement. He said voters will recognize that Labour has brought stability and growth, and will continue to do so. Meanwhile, the Conservatives outlined their plans to tackle 'yob culture' and the Liberal Democrats gave more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties, urging them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to run in Sheffield, AAA's sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed in mid-week that he would join Cragg in the European championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment, with Cragg occupying top spot.

Robinson, a former rugby league international, has targeted dual code success for England against Australia on Saturday. As a former rugby league international, Robinson has switched codes in 2000, and he leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 2 30pm GMT. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as gaining revenge for June's 51-15 hammering by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of failure against Australia with victory at Elland Road.

Warning  Scammers are targeting net users with a fake website claiming to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate due to its use of an outdated version of the official disaster relief webpage. However, it has no affiliation with the real site and has allegedly contacted the authorities about it. This is just the latest in a long list of scams attempting to profit from the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is included in a spam email with a subject line reading "Urgent  Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and its text bearing all the poor grammar and bad spelling typical of many other phishing attempts.

Iraq invites phone license bids: Iraq is inviting bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, Arab and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications said. The winner will work in partnership with Iraq's telecommunications and postal company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from around 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years. It also hopes to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunications sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on February 9. Additionally, it is planning a road-show for investors in Amman, Jordan.

According to a two-year study, more women are taking charge of protecting their home computers against malicious net attacks, with an increasing trend. The number of women buying programs to safeguard their PCs from virus, spam, and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted by a net security firm, reveals that security messages are reaching a diverse range of surfers. Notably, 40% of those purchasing home net security programs are retired individuals. Over the past three years, this trend has increased by an average of 13.2%. Interestingly, more retired women (53%) than retired men are buying security software, reflecting the evolving demographics and growing awareness of the greater risks associated with high-speed broadband net connections among surfers.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio with digital music players, which can hold up to 10,000 songs, offering a vast space to fill. With more and more iPod owners filling that space with audio content created by an eclectic assortment of producers, podcasting has emerged as a popular trend. Its strongest proponent is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, although you don't need an iPod to create one or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show, which podcasters create in the comfort of their own homes. They require only a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them, all for free.

Levy wins Whitbread novel prize, orange prize winner Andrea Levy has seen her book, 'Small Island', win the Whitbread novel of the year award. She is now a strong favourite to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's 'The Line of Beauty'. Geraldine McCaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for 'Not the End of the World'. All category winners go through to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant and writer Joanne Harris, will meet up on January 25 to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

Yukos seeks court action in the US on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that has acquired its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal, which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion rubles, £4.8 billion) on Sunday at a state-sponsored auction, has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.

Hearts 2-1 livingston hearts wrapped up their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour, but Hearts held on. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken had clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister floated the free kick into the Livi box and Miller outjumped the static visiting defense to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Jamie Jamieson, Scotland's justice minister, has issued a warning to bigoted soccer fans, stating that she intends to take action "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. This is part of a series of measures being considered by the Scottish Executive to combat sectarianism. Jamieson praised Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the issue, emphasizing that stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective. The minister was speaking ahead of the third round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism, long associated with sections of the support from both clubs, has become a significant target for the executive. Last week, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnel met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, "Beyond the Sea", in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. The event was held in honor of the Hollywood star's tribute to the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of Bobby Darin, who sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, Sandra Dee, a real-life Hollywood actress. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Friday) Headingley, 25 February 2000 GMT  The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee on loan while fly-half Craig McMillan has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley got the go-ahead on Friday after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds  Balshaw, Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements  Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMullan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones may soon face an uncertain future, as the fixed line phone in your home could become an endangered species. Research by Nokia, a leading handset maker, reveals that more and more people are using their mobile phones for every call they make or take. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, US, and South Korea now only use a mobile. The study found that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls, but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles and to friends. In the UK, 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.
