The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. The proposed reform plan aims to raise the pressure on Tony Blair over reform to the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The group has tried to raise the pressure on Tony Blair over reform to the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. Mps and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditaries lost their seats. The group says it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the lords. Tony Blair has argued. There needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions there will be proposals for changing at least the powers of the lords in Labour's manifesto.

Scott Allan is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A woman in the US is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP) over its printer ink cartridges, claiming they are secretly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia alleges that a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it needs to be refilled, even when it's not empty. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, has declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and prompt the user to make a change. However, the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website, which enables the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, said  "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland said  "This application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music on the Isle of Wight will appear at the Isle of Wight Music Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The festival takes place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzarek, Andy McKay, and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, McKay, and Brian Eno, with Manzarek joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's 'Virginia Plain', with other hits including 'Street Life', 'Love is the Drug', and the 1981 John Lennon cover, 'Jealous Guy'.

Captains lining up for the aid match, Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the Ireland Rugby Aid match on March 5. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a Tsumani fund-raising match at Twickenham. 'I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players,' he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. 'The game promises to be a great spectacle,' he said.

Spirit awards hail the comedy "Sideways" as this year's independent spirit awards' dominant winner, taking home all six awards for which it was nominated. It was named best film, while Alexander Payne won best director and best screenplay, alongside writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. "Sideways" is expected to perform well at the Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, recognize films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took home the best actress award for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace." Moreno is also nominated for best actress at the Oscars. The best first screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for "Maria Full of Grace."

Prince, crowned the 'top music earner' in 2004, earned more than any other pop star, surpassing Madonna and Elton John, according to US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer banked $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concerts, album, and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. He outearned Madonna, who took second place, earning $54.9 million (£29.5 million) while embarking on her global re-invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9 million (£13.4 million) last year. "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. His 2004 tour took in $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

U2, the Irish band, have been honored at France's biggest music awards, but were beaten to a prize by the boy band Blue. U2 received a special achievement prize at the NRJ music awards, but Blue beat them to the international group award. U2 was named the best new international artist, and took the best international song title for 'Beautiful Day.' More than five million radio listeners voted in the awards. The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively. Collecting his band's award from model Naomi Campbell at the Cannes ceremony, U2 frontman Bono said in French  'I'm not from this country, but I'll make a little confession to you - it's at the Côte d'Azur I feel at home.'

Walmart fights back at accusers with two big US names, launching advertising campaigns to set the record straight about their products and corporate behavior. The world's biggest retailer, Walmart, took out more than 100 full-page adverts in national newspapers. The group aims to dispel criticism over it pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, drug company Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart kicked off the battle with adverts in newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, using an open letter from company President Lee Scott, saying it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth". "There are lots of 'urban legends' going around these days about Walmart, but facts are facts.

The plans unveiled by the conservatives would ask local communities to elect their own area police commissioner. The party leader, Michael Howard, stated that the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He emphasized that the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats criticized the plan, saying it could lead to extreme groups controlling policing, while Labour described the Conservative's promises on policing as "extravagant." The chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, representing rank-and-file officers, emphasized the importance of retaining operational independence. Jan Berry warned, "It is essential that operational independence is retained. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground.

At a glance  Tory health checks for immigrants  a guide to the UK's proposed plan. The UK's opposition conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan  individuals coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with a high incidence of TB, they would have to undergo a chest X-ray and further tests if deemed necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical examination. This will include tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive test for TB would automatically result in visa applications being denied. All other conditions would be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

Paris's promise raises Welsh hopes has seen a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? Those are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in." A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed  "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half."

Doves soar to the top of the UK album chart with their new release, dethroning flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters. The trio's album follows the success of their single "Black and White Town", which peaked at number six. Meanwhile, R&B star Nelly has the new number one single with "Over and Over", a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, as do Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, "(Marie's the Name)" of his latest flame, enters the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up". Hip-hop performer Akon's "Locked Up" is at number five, while hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with "Oh My God."

Davies favours Gloucester's future, with Mefin Davies likely to stay with the English side despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. According to BBC Wales, the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to remain with Gloucester. As one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, Davies is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, he has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies without a contract, forcing him to take a semi-professional deal with Neath RFC. Although he received match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was angry with the way he was treated.

Cabinet ministers express anger at plans to use Whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr. Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. He stated that local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr. Raynsford said nearly all central government departments had an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin looks to Africa for four African players, including Zimbabwe goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, who are all set to play for the club in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin is the first Arab side to participate in a European competition and will face English Premier League side Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin overcome Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro recently joined the club after a brief stint with South African club Hellas. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club has a strong ethos and is a prominent promoter of peace and cooperation within Israel.

New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. According to a university college London research, cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety as MPs are due to vote on the government's road safety bill, which includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, suggests that cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads compared to 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119 million a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested that such a move could save 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1x1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512x512 μm². Unlike traditional approaches, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline, rather than sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation. This eliminates the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system-optimal routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have made it possible to prepare macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. This new capability has enabled the idea of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility to escape this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed non-classical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make informed decisions. Unfortunately, the evaluations can be manipulated by professional spammers using fake reviews ("spams") that have evolved to evade detection. Spamming strategies are difficult to capture, as they can adapt quickly over time, vary across spammers and target products, and remain unknown in most cases. Moreover, existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not well-aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product reviews. To address the challenges, we propose a minimax game where spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical goals, which are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot, shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a three-level quantum system in a lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above 10^-4. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we investigate the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to non-convexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima share the same structural form that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture, in the sense that each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $x_m$ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, Berglund-H\"ubsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by some dual group $g^t$. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this study, a generalization of the study on human gait analysis was derived from existing models in the literature, including those of Keller and Kocksenev. In this hybrid model, a metabolic energy minimization strategy is combined with a non-linear description of the mass center's libration, aiming to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. Experimental data for different speed regimes indicate that the perimeter of the mass center's trajectory is a relevant quantity in the quantification of this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories at the Manuel Beltran University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a novel mixed-variable symplectic integrator for planetary systems, capable of fully resolving close encounters. The method is based on a time regularization technique that preserves the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during close encounters. We employ a high-order mvs scheme, enabling integration with large time steps far from close encounters. We demonstrate that this algorithm is capable of resolving almost exact collisions (i.e., with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problems, such as the solar system. We show the long-term behavior of systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods such as Mercury and demonstrate that, for an equivalent cost, we achieve much better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a crucial resource for processing quantum information. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In reality, as the Hilbert-space dimension exponentially increases with respect to the system size, it is extremely challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For n-partite GHZ-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires n+1 local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/2 white noise. In comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/3 white noise.

In general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which exhibits a peculiar multipolar structure dependent solely on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and exhibit a much richer multipolar structure, providing a gateway to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates impose only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will significantly improve these bounds by orders of magnitude.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in various domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common scenario in which edges can be short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendships). In practice, long-term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both costly to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To alleviate these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. As temporal attention drives between-node feature propagation, using the dynamics of node interactions to learn this key component provides more flexibility while simultaneously avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibrations of a photonic crystal waveguide are reported. The waveguide consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for transducing beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode of the waveguide for probe frequencies both far from and near the dielectric band edge. Since our waveguide has been designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating potential deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of waveguides. Longer-term goals are to achieve strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the guided modes of the waveguide, thereby enabling optomechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting stems from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences separate into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as Euclid or LSST. In this first paper of a series of two, we use simulations to build a Euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, which are both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, enabling us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard LCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

In spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, we have seen that processing audio files can be particularly challenging. However, building speech processing models that can handle a wide variety of conditions would be particularly useful for language acquisition studies, where researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of the speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring the effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To this end, we have gathered diverse child-centered corpora, which totals 260 hours of recordings and spans 10 languages.

Density-based clustering relies on linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. By referencing a true, unknown, population structure, we frame the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, establishes a correspondence between groups and domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, along with a proper selection of the amount of smoothing, which governs the shape of the density and potentially the modal structure, to identify the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between the standard model and higher-dimensional operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes set an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail, and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable, which is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is the primary goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often frowned upon data analysis with a causal objective. The introduction of the term "data science" presents a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in a way that naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks  description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which includes causal inference). A clear classification of data science tasks is essential to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task. We argue that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a source of widespread misunderstandings about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) demands the existence of super-extremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore suggests that these particles are introduced to ensure that extreme black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it is unclear what would be wrong if this doesn't happen. This note shows that, for a generic Einsteinian quantum theory of gravity in AdS, the stability of extreme black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding the contradiction leads to a non-perturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general, and it does not rely on either supersymmetry or a particular UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding the strong correlations between two-dimensional (2D) systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity at high critical temperatures, a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v_c. We measure v_c as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful tool for investigating the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) are a mathematical model widely used in various application areas, such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, due to their intuitive appeal for modeling. Despite the widespread use of ODEs in modeling, the frequent absence of their analytical solutions makes it challenging to estimate ODE parameters from the data, particularly when the model has numerous variables and parameters. This paper proposes a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is both fast and accurate, even for models with many parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model based on equations of a numeric solver, allowing for fast estimation by avoiding the computation of a whole numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained by a variational Bayes method, specifically, the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Hönkelä et al.

We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Remarkably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been utilized in a number of applications. Notably, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby enabling the application of higher operational voltages without surface flashover. However, a concern for the use of this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. Here, we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that, after an initial drop of approximately 40% in the first few weeks following implantation, the conductivity exhibits a very slow decrease of around 10% over the ensuing year.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, built upon the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Furthermore, there exist singular configurations that can be identified as n_f=1 baryons charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, the vector mesons play the role of the Chern-Simons vector fields living on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current is the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified picture for the two types of baryons, allowing them to continuously transform into each other in a natural manner. Additionally, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions provides an intriguing means to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We theoretically investigate how the superposition of both effects affects the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially established to quantify usual (tunneling) Josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are widely adjustable via the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a clear spectroscopic fingerprint of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.

Following the suggestion from the Monte Carlo experiments in Jimenez (2020), it is found that dipoles are as crucial to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores. It is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a family of small, fast-moving cores and another family of larger, slowly moving ones, which can be described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of both families are very different, and only the former is self-similar. The latter is responsible for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and the streams. Mechanisms are discussed for the growth of this slow-moving component.

Continuous-time quantum walks have been proven to be an extremely useful framework for the design of several quantum algorithms. Often, the running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time  the time required for the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. In this article, we provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several continuous-time quantum walk-based quantum algorithms. In particular, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, improving their hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor  from O(n^5) to O(n^2 log n). Moreover, our methods also enable exponentially improved dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain by Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered as the main EMRI sources for the laser interferometer space antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel  (wet) EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that are initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH, boosting the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about him/her, i.e., no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems to attract the users at the first time so that the users decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into the new user cold-start category and is crucial to the development and survival of a company. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, e.g., setting up an interview process, or make use of side information such as user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to take the interview and side information on cold-start users is usually not available.

Deep learning has successfully solved many problems that are beyond the reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even though the current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been achieved by learning individual parts of a receiver, a better approach is to jointly learn the whole receiver. This, however, often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is difficult to implement. To address this, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which executes the whole receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5g-compliant manner. We facilitate accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically employs an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs, a corpus, from which to generate new inputs through mutation. This corpus of potential seeds often contains thousands of similar inputs. The lack of diversity in this corpus can lead to inefficient fuzzing efforts by exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers come with distillation tools, such as afl-cmin, that select the smallest subset of seeds that trigger the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. It is common practice to suggest that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we systematically explore. Our results from 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches reveal the impact in finding bugs in real-world software.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be grouped into several categories, each comprising agents with similar (isomorphic) state transition structures, which can be relabeled to the same template. Based on this template, a scalable supervisor is designed for the case of partial observation, whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not require re-computation regardless of the number of agents added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximum permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for ENF estimation is introduced, utilizing temporal windowing based on the filter-bank capon spectral estimator. A type of Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is employed due to the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach utilizes a temporal window, not necessarily rectangular, at the stage preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are leveraged for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in ENF estimation, when a short time window of 1 second is employed in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results with respect to both time complexity and accuracy.

The direpack package aims to establish a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques as a single, consistent package, providing a unified interface to the python universe. The dimension reduction methods include three categories  projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are also provided, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also includes a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Finally, direpack has been written to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, ensuring seamless integration into (statistical and/or machine) learning pipelines within the framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for high-resolution optical imaging. Here, we investigated the fluorescence anomalous saturation effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. The fluorescence reduction was observed with high-power laser excitation. It increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission, and altered the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We employed a differential excitation protocol to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, we improved the spatial resolution of imaging, approximately 1.6 times higher than confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we anticipate this method can be used for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling in solids.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the traditional approach of using individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We contrast our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration to reveal that only the Bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real-data examples for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a culmination for recent developmental efforts that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling paradigm, providing a bridge across the two rich but disparate subfields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials, such as res2 and rese2 monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, and others, exhibit more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties, including ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also occur due to low symmetry. The 'Beyond Graphene  Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials' special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were studied using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be presented by a sum of several exponential processes, with two processes playing a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of approximately 50 degrees Celsius. Dielectric spectroscopy also enabled the distinction of two orientational relaxation processes  the first is attributed to the rotation of side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with the motion of main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated exceptional retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. The primary focus in these methods is on optimizing discrete hash bits. A common strategy in these methods is to adopt an activation function, for instance, the sigmoid or tanh, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm may lead to more and more hash bits being stuck in the wrong region of the activation functions, failing to escape. We refer to this issue as the 'dead bits problem'. Moreover, the existing quantization loss will exacerbate dbp. In this paper, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier that acts before activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We study the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the standard model Higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multi-lepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, and an unstable triplet with a mass less than 230 GeV is excluded at 95% confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, often referred to as the pericenter glow. The standard scenario assumes an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis a, whose eccentricity is increased to ef after the gas disc has dispersed by secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width 2ae_f. A minor modification of this scenario, however, suggests that narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.

An electron is typically considered to possess only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, due to its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is captured well at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate Fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, together with the emergence of three additional 1D'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the Gaia mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the Milky Way has experienced. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by Gaia for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. Results show that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article illustrates intrinsic, an R package that implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. In detail, the methods included in this package are the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To make these novel estimators easily accessible, the package contains a few high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models that fall into two categories  homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category contains the two-nn and gride models. The functions dedicated to these two methods perform inference under both the frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. In the second category, we find hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recursive behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems, based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNOs with current pulse stimulation indicate that a handwritten digits recognition task can be domesticated by an RC system using a single MSM, achieving outstanding performance on image classification. Additionally, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be well solved by a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOs confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings  the fewer items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of the overall traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer effect emerges in settings where there are few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that this few-get-richer effect arises when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items. Through simulations, we analyze how the strength of the effect changes with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also test our predictions experimentally in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings have important implications for understanding the spread of misinformation.

Weight pruning has been widely recognized as a straightforward and effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, leading to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this issue, we introduce a novel sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity, which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity, and proves to be highly accurate and hardware-friendly. With carefully designed patterns, our approach consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability on different DNN structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework also enables pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern, and connectivity pruning and weight training simultaneously. Our approach naturally fits seamlessly into compiler optimization for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from a treated group is susceptible to bias from historical events that have distinct effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in reduced bias. We examine this phenomenon in simulation studies. We investigate the effect of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that leverages the increase in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of MRM on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval that encompasses substantial adverse effects alongside no effect and small beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved through visual predictive checks (VPC), which consist of (1) several replicates of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is straightforward to apply, in general. Here, we consider the application of the method to time-to-event data and consider the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are demonstrated. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can enable us to  (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.

Palms sweating, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it would be so embarrassing. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster; you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death. See, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try and overcome it. To start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, 'What if people think I'm awful and I'm an idiot?'

I can't think of anyone who has only one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. Around 15% of American workers don't have traditional full-time jobs; they're half-time, part-time, contract workers or temps. The term "side hustle" seems to fit with this ethos, where people are piecing together a few different things to make a living. The word "side hustle" has its roots in popular African American newspapers. By the 1950s, these papers used the term "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam, but by the 1950s, they were also using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work. A side hustle is distinct from a second job, which is often about necessity.

Two opposing design cultures, each with its own distinct character. One is comprised of thousands of steel components, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed upon the environment, the other creates it. Michelangelo once said that when he gazed at raw marble, he saw a figure yearning to be free. The chisel was Michelangelo's only tool. However, living things are not chiseled. They grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we harbor all the information necessary for every other cell to function and replicate. Like tools, our bodies also have consequences. At least since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous when you're on stage, picture people in the audience undressed? It's like it's this thing that's supposed to make you feel more at ease. But I was thinking - picturing all of you undressed in 2018 feels kind of awkward and uncomfortable. Like, we're working really hard on moving past things like that, so we need a new approach to dealing with if you get nervous on stage. It's often said that doing two things at once is to do neither, and it's often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus. However, it's unclear whether he actually said this. What I'm interested in is whether it's true. While it's certainly true for activities like emailing at the dinner table, texting while driving, or live tweeting at a TED Talk, it's not necessarily true for all tasks. In fact, for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once – or three or even four – is exactly what we should aim for. Albert Einstein, in 1905, published four remarkable scientific papers, demonstrating his ability to focus on multiple tasks simultaneously.

I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better humans. As I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the birthplace of Bethlehem Steel, my father, an engineer, would teach me how things functioned. We would construct projects together, such as model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. Sustainability represents the what, where, and how of what is caught. The who and the why behind my dinner choices are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices and how they impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish and how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also fortunate to eat. So, we call this restorative seafood. Sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, while restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

The starving orphan, seeking a second helping of gruel, the spinster, wasting away in her tattered wedding dress, the stone-hearted miser, plagued by the ghost of Christmas past, more than a century after his death, remain recognizable figures from the work of Charles Dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of Dickens's writing that make it so special? Dickens's fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.

I'd like to tell you about the future of money, starting with a fascinating story about the Yap culture, which thrived in Micronesia in the early 1900s. The Yap people used a unique form of currency, limestone discs called Rai stones, which are truly remarkable. Unlike our modern coins, the Yap didn't physically move these Rai stones around or exchange them; instead, they kept track of who owned a portion of what stone. The largest Rai stone is about four tons and 12 feet across, so it's easy to understand why the Yap didn't bother to transport them. Interestingly, there's a story about sailors who were transporting a stone across the ocean when they encountered some trouble, and the stone actually fell in.

You've been accused of a crime you didn't commit. It's impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist on claiming your innocence, you'll likely be found guilty and executed. However, if you confess, apologize, and implicate others, you'll be set free. Do you give a false confession or risk a public hanging? This was the difficult choice facing those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor, and a justice system that prioritized repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by the Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of Salem, marked by frequent battles with their Native American neighbors and French settlers.

There are hundreds of thousands of people currently on transplant waiting lists, waiting for life-saving organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers. Unfortunately, there aren't nearly enough available donor organs to meet that demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That's the concept behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. While we're not yet able to print complex organs, we're already making progress on simpler tissues, including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one layer at a time.

Good afternoon, I'm thrilled to be speaking at TEDxKrakow today. I'll attempt to share a little bit about a phenomenon that is indeed changing the world, and whose name is people power. We're about to embark on a journey in 1964. Bob Dylan, 23 years young, is at the peak of his career, hailed as the voice of a generation, and churning out timeless classics at an astonishing pace. However, a small minority of detractors claim that Bob Dylan is plagiarizing other artists' work. In 2004, Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, takes the Beatles' "White Album" and Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." This unexpected fusion sparks an instant online sensation, prompting the Beatles' record company to send out numerous cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." Interestingly, "The Grey Album" is now officially classified as a remix.

Currently, most refugees reside in cities rather than in refugee camps. We account for over 60% of the global refugee population. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can not only help themselves but also contribute to the development of their host country. I was born in the city of Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.

I have two questions for you  whose shoulders do you stand on, and what do you stand for? These are two questions I always ask my students at the start of my poetry workshops, as poetry can sometimes seem like a dying art form, exclusive to old, white men who seem destined to be old, like Benjamin Button or someone. I ask my students these questions, and then I share how I answer them, which is in three sentences that I repeat as a mantra before every poetry performance  I am the daughter of black writers, descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. I often repeat these words in the corner over there, making faces.

On October 4, 1957, the world witnessed a pivotal moment in history as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite, into space. This small, two-foot-diameter metal sphere sparked a space race between the US and USSR that would last for eighteen years and revolutionize our understanding of the world. Interestingly, Sputnik was not the first human-made object to venture into space. That distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket, used by Germany during World War II in missile attacks against Allied cities. Although ineffective, the V-2 rocket technology and its scientists were captured by both the US and USSR at the war's end, and were subsequently repurposed for their own projects.

We need more ambition from all  governments, cities, businesses, investors, and individuals everywhere. I am pleased you are launching the Countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science, and the resources. Let us now get into this race with political will and energy.

Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? As I speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, I can tell you that it's exhausting – it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag, hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class, rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings, pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.

The world's largest and most significant environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, Canada's boreal forest. It spans across northern Canada, including Labrador, where it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world – the George River caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, during my visit, I couldn't find one of them, but I have the antlers as proof. Throughout the boreal forest, we're fortunate to have this incredible abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are one of the most endangered ecosystems. They're absolutely crucial ecosystems, as they purify the air, clean the water, sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and provide a home to a vast diversity of species.

At the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Alongside that, what we now know as planets, comets, and asteroids formed. According to theory, when the Earth had cooled slightly after its formation, comets massively impacted the Earth, delivering water and possibly complex organic material, which may have kickstarted the emergence of life.

In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping trip in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, braved a snowstorm, and spent hours engaging in lively conversation around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist John Muir. Roosevelt was famously enamored with the outdoors, but Muir had invited him to Yosemite for more than just a camping excursion  the valley was in danger. Although Yosemite had been protected land since 1864, it was still at risk of overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-long struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use – two goals that were easier said than done. The battle over Yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners flocked west, seeking gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

One single vitamin can significantly reduce the risk of heart disease. Eating chocolate can help reduce stress in students. To avoid being misled by grabby headlines, it's essential to assess a headline's credibility by looking at the original research it reports on. We've developed a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines. Keep watching for the explanation of the first example; then pause at the headline to answer the question. So, when I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from Ethiopia. And one day my mom asked, 'What day should we celebrate for their birthday?' 'Uh, the day they were born, obviously?' was a ridiculous question. Then my mom said, 'Well, Kristin, neither of your little brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we figure out when that was?' Mind blown. Now, 20 years later, I'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, I try to solve this problem globally. So, what do birth certificates have to do with international development?

Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? That's the question philosopher Robert Nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch is that you would have to permanently leave reality behind, but you wouldn't even notice the difference. Your experiences would be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs would simply be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, doesn't it?

For the past 24 years, I have been a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. As firefighters, my team and I are tasked with saving lives and property from disasters such as car wrecks, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. I am a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession. Ten years ago, I decided to enhance my medical knowledge, and I received a nursing degree. This was because it became clear that the next big threat facing not only my city, but also cities around the country, was not the one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry, as a firefighter, put out the fire and leave, feeling like you've made a difference, and everything is okay.

Where does all the carbon dioxide we release go? Carbon plays a natural cycle, present in all living things  in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere, and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living organisms die, much of their stored carbon is released back to the atmosphere, where it's reabsorbed by new plants and organisms. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock, and some becomes fossil fuels  coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release approximately 60 times more carbon dioxide than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.

Even nature's most reviled creatures possess important secrets, but who would welcome a swarm of cockroaches approaching them? Yet, one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies lies in robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and novel environments. Notably, cockroaches can self-stabilize while running over rough terrain. When we equipped them with a jet pack or subjected them to a perturbation like an earthquake, we found that their exquisitely tuned legs enable self-stabilization without requiring any brainpower. They can traverse complex terrain like grass without issue, and remain unstabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, due to their shape, they automatically roll onto their side to navigate this artificial grass obstacle. Robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same architecture. Here, we've uncovered a new behavior.

The other day, I was reading something, and the person said, probably the largest single cause of disease is handshaking in the West.

What is a parent? What is a parent? It's not an easy question. Today, we have adoption, stepfamilies, and surrogate mothers. Many parents face tough questions and tough decisions. Should we tell our child about the sperm donation? If so, when, and with what words? Sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but should we really be using the word "father" as a title? As a philosopher and social scientist, I have been studying these questions about the concept of parenthood. But today, I will talk to you about what I learned from talking to parents and children. I will show you that they know what matters most in a family, even though their family may look a little different.

When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State Senator. Instead, it was a learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to something I didn't think was possible for me or our justice system as a whole. We need to build a weather service for water. However, until we collectively demand accountability, the incentives to fund it will not exist. The first time I spoke at a conference was here at TED, eight years ago. I was wrong.
